snippet: The thundering rumbles that elephants use to communicate are produced by a mechanism more akin to the way people talk or sing than to the way cats purr, say scientists who analyzed an elephant larynx.
abstract: Study in journal Science finds that elephants produce their distinctive rumbling sounds by blowing air past their long vocal folds, in much the same way that people talk or sing.

byline.original: By SINDYA N. BHANOO and KATE YANDELL

lead_paragraph: The thundering rumbles that elephants use to communicate are produced by a mechanism more akin to the way people talk or sing than to the way cats purr, say scientists who analyzed an elephant larynx.

headline.print_headline: How to Tell an Elephant From a Cat? Check the Larynx
headline.seo: Elephants’ Rumble Is More Like Talking Than Purring, Larynx Study Finds
headline.main: How to Tell an Elephant From a Cat? Check the Larynx
